revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2015}} {{Year nav topic5|1705|music}}
The year '''1705 in music''' involved some significant events.
==Events== *[[Johann Sebastian Bach]] travels to Lübeck to hear [[Dieterich Buxtehude]] perform.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clare|first1=Horatio|title=With Bach to the Baltic: a hike through German history|url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2017/dec/18/js-bach-baltic-walking-germany-history-lubeck-mountains|website=the Guardian|accessdate=16 April 2018|language=en|date=18 December 2017}}</ref> *[[Alessandro Scarlatti]] notes that he has written 88 operas in the past 23 years.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scarlatti: La Folia & other works|url=https://www.hyperion-records.co.uk/dc.asp?dc=D_CDH55233|website=Hyperion Records|accessdate=16 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> *[[William Croft]] marries Mary George.<ref>{{cite web|title=William Croft|url=http://www.westminster-abbey.org/our-history/people/william-croft|website=www.westminster-abbey.org|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref> *[[Jean-Féry Rebel]] joins [[Les Vingt-quatre Violons du Roi]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rebel – Francoeur|url=http://www.stradivaria.org/programmes/fery-rebel/|website=www.stradivaria.org|accessdate=16 April 2018|language=fr-FR}}</ref> *The earliest [[fandango]] melody is recorded in the anonymous ''Libro de diferentes cifras de guitarra''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Duckett|first1=George A.|title=Etymology: Questions and Answers|date=2018|publisher=George A Duckett|page=1952|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=fF1RDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT1952|language=en}}</ref>
==Classical music== *[[Friedrich Nicolaus Brauns]] – ''St Mark Passion'' (formerly attributed to [[Reinhard Keiser]])
==Opera== The following [[opera]]s were composed: *[[Antonio Caldara]] – ''L'Arminia'' *[[Thomas Clayton (opera)|Thomas Clayton]], [[Nicola Haym]], & [[Charles Dieupart]] – ''Arsinoe, Queen of Cyprus'', produced at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane Theatre]] in [[London]] *[[Francesco Gasparini]] – ''Statira'' *[[George Frideric Handel]] – ''[[Almira]]'', premièred in [[Hamburg]]
== Births == *[[January 24]] – [[Farinelli]], celebrated ''castrato'' (died [[1782 in music|1782]]) *[[February 20]] – [[Nicolas Chédeville]], composer, musette player and maker (died [[1782 in music|1782]]) *[[September 19]] – [[Marguerite-Antoinette Couperin]], French harpsichordist (died [[1778 in music|1778]]) *[[September 28]] – [[Johann Peter Kellner]], organist and composer (died [[1772 in music|1772]]) *[[November 5]] – [[Louis-Gabriel Guillemain]], composer and violinist (died [[1770 in music|1770]]) *[[November 29]] – [[Michael Christian Festing]], violinist and composer (died [[1752 in music|1752]]) *''date unknown'' **[[Louis Archimbaud]], organist and composer (died 1789) **[[Nicola Sabatino]], composer (died 1796) *''probable'' – [[Joseph-Nicolas-Pancrace Royer]], composer and harpsichordist (died [[1755]])
== Deaths == *February – [[Pierre Beauchamp]], dancer, choreographer and composer (born 1631) *[[February 5]] – [[Jean Gilles (composer)|Jean Gilles]], composer (born 1668) *[[June 13]] – [[Nicholas Staggins]], composer, Master of the King's Musick *[[April 17]] – [[Johann Paul von Westhoff]], violinist and composer (born 1656) *[[December 1]] – [[Jeremiah Clarke]], composer (born c. 1674) *''probable'' – [[Giovanni Battista Rogeri]], luthier (born c. 1650)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1705 in music| ]] [[Category:18th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Catalog-Exhibition-LOSH-60-bw.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=200px | title=Annual Exhibition of Leningrad Artists. 1960. Catalog | artist= | year=1960 | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]] | museum=[[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists|Leningrad Union of Artists Exhibition Halls]] }} '''Annual Exhibition of Leningrad artists (Leningrad, 1960)''' ({{lang-ru|italic=yes|"Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1960 года"}}) become one of the largest Soviet Art Exhibition of 1960 year. The Exhibition took place in [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists|Leningrad Union of Soviet Artists Exhibition Halls]] on Bolshaya Morskaya st. 38.
== History and Organization == For the organization and preparation of the Annual Art Exhibition of 1960 was formed specially Exhibition Committee which consisted of the most authoritative art-experts. Exhibition Catalog was published.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1960 года. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1963.</ref> In total, the Exhibition displayed almost 650 works of art of painters, sculptors, graphics, artists of theater and cinema, masters of arts and crafts. In total exhibition attended by 300 artists of the Leningrad.
== Contributing Artists == In the largest Department of Painting were exhibited art works of 167 authors. There were [[Taisia Afonina]], [[Piotr Alberti]], [[Evgenia Antipova]], Genrikh Bagrov, [[Leonid Baykov]], [[Vsevolod Bazhenov]], [[Nikolai Baskakov (painter)|Nikolai Baskakov]], [[Zlata Bizova]], [[Olga Bogaevskaya]], [[Lev Bogomolets]], [[Nikolai Galakhov]], [[Vladimir Gorb]], [[Abram Grushko]], [[German Egoshin]], [[Alexei Eriomin]], [[Mikhail Kaneev]], [[Maria Kleschar-Samokhvalova]], [[Boris Korneev]], [[Alexander Koroviakov]], [[Victor Korovin]], [[Elena Kostenko]], [[Nikolai Kostrov]], [[Anna Kostrova]], [[Gevork Kotiantz]], [[Mikhail Kozell]], [[Marina Kozlovskaya]], [[Yaroslav Krestovsky]], [[Boris Lavrenko]], [[Ivan Lavsky]], [[Oleg Lomakin]], [[Dmitry Maevsky]], [[Vladimir Malevsky]], [[Alexei Mozhaev]], [[Evsey Moiseenko]], [[Nikolai Mukho]], [[Andrei Mylnikov]], [[Piotr Nazarov]], [[Vera Nazina]], [[Mikhail Natarevich]], [[Samuil Nevelshtein]], [[Dmitry Oboznenko]], [[Sergei Ivanovich Osipov|Sergei Osipov]], [[Lia Ostrova]], [[Filaret Pakun]], [[Varlen Pen]], [[Boris Stepanovich Petrov|Boris Petrov]], [[Nikolai Pozdneev]], [[Stepan Privedentsev]], [[Valentina Rakhina]], [[Semion Rotnitsky]], [[Maria Rudnitskaya]], [[Vladimir Sakson]], [[Samokhvalov Alexander|Alexander Samokhvalov]], [[Ivan Savenko]], [[Alexander Mikhailovich Semionov|Alexander Semionov]], [[Arseny Semionov]], [[Yuri Shablikin]], [[Boris Shamanov]], [[Alexander Shmidt]], [[Elena Skuin]], [[Alexander Ivanovich Sokolov|Alexander Sokolov]], [[Alexander Stolbov]], [[Victor Teterin]], [[Nikolai Timkov]], [[Yuri Tulin]], [[Boris Ugarov]], [[Ivan Varichev]], [[Rostislav Vovkushevsky]], [[Vecheslav Zagonek]], [[Ruben Zakharian]], [[Elena Zhukova]], and others most prominent painters of the [[Leningrad School of Painting|Leningrad School]].<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1960 года. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1963.</ref>
In the Department of Sculptures were exhibited art works of 44 sculptors. Department of graphics presented a creation of 84 artists.
== Contributed Artworks ==
For the Exhibition were selected art works created in 1959-1960, also some earlier works. All they were exhibited in the first time. Some of them were subsequently found in the collections of Soviet Art museums, as well as domestic and foreign galleries and collectors.
'''Portrait''' was presented of ''"Grandmother with a granddaughter"'' by [[Nikolai Baskakov (painter)|Nikolai Baskakov]], ''"Verochka"'' by [[Maria Kleschar-Samokhvalova]], ''"Misha"'', ''"Katenka"'' by [[Elena Kostenko]], ''"Portrait of wife with daughter"'' by [[Gevork Kotiantz]], ''"A worker of rolling mill"'' by [[Dmitry Maevsky]], ''"Natasha"'', ''"Portrait of artist Vasily Meshkov"'', ''"Portrait of Wife"'' by [[Evsey Moiseenko]], ''"Verochka at the window"'' by [[Andrei Mylnikov]], ''"Nadenka"'' by [[Vera Nazina]], ''"Schoolboy"'' by [[Samuil Nevelshtein]], ''"Portrait of Partisan"'' by [[Semion Rotnitsky]], ''"Tonia"'' by [[Boris Ugarov]], ''"Portrait of a woman - worker of Publishing"'' by [[Ruben Zakharian]], and others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1960 года. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1963.</ref>
'''Genre painting''' was presented of ''"Crossing"'' by [[Nikolai Galakhov]], ''"At the stables"'' by [[Abram Grushko]], ''"Camp of geologists"'' by [[Alexei Eriomin]], ''"On the [[Neva River]]"'' by [[Ivan Lavsky]], ''"Pig farm workers"'', ''"Lunch break"'' by [[Oleg Lomakin]], ''"Construction"'' by [[Nikolai Mukho]], ''"At the breakfast"'', "In Studio" by [[Andrei Mylnikov]], ''"Rendezvous"'', ''"In a walk"'' by [[Mikhail Natarevich]], ''"Whistle-stop"'' by [[Samuil Nevelshtein]], ''"Wharf in [[Kizhi Pogost]]"'' by [[Dmitry Oboznenko]], ''"Winter camp on the [[Neva River]]"'' by [[Boris Stepanovich Petrov|Boris Petrov]], ''"Cafe Gurzuf"'', ''"At the Seaside highway"'' by [[Samokhvalov Alexander|Alexander Samokhvalov]], ''"Port in the night"'' by [[Yuri Shablikin]], ''"Smoke of the Magnitogorsk steel plant"'' by [[Alexander Ivanovich Sokolov|Alexander Sokolov]], ''"A Summer"'' by [[Victor Teterin]], ''"Gold fields of [[Artyomovsk, Russia|Artyomovsk]]"'', ''"The City is under construction"'' by [[Yuri Tulin]], "Tonia" by and others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1960 года. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1963.</ref>
'''Landscape and Cityscape''' were presented of ''"On the [[Zhdanovka River]]"'' by [[Taisia Afonina]], ''"On the [[Senezh Lake]]"'' by [[Piotr Alberti]], ''"Northern wind"'', ''"A Shore of the lake"'', ''"A Village of Tarasy"'' by [[Leonid Baykov]], ''"Twilight"'', ''"In the Wood"'' by [[Vsevolod Bazhenov]], ''"A Spring"'' by [[Zlata Bizova]], ''"Evening Sky"'' by [[Lev Bogomolets]], ''"Small Courtyard"'' by [[Vladimir Gorb]], ''"In Spring"'', ''"February"'' by [[Abram Grushko]], ''"Etude"'', ''"Old courtyard"'' by [[German Egoshin]], ''"October"'', ''"Northern etude"'', ''"Forest Lake"'' by [[Alexei Eriomin]], ''"Leningrad courtyard"'' by [[Mikhail Kaneev]], ''"Twilight"'', ''"By the evening"'' by [[Boris Korneev]], ''"[[Kronverksky Strait]]"'' by [[Alexander Koroviakov]], ''"[[Yaroslavl]]. A View from the Spassky monastery"'' by [[Victor Korovin]], ''"Winter etude"'' by [[Mikhail Kozell]], ''"Evening"'', ''"Karelian landscape"'', ''"Highway"'' by [[Marina Kozlovskaya]], ''"Old houses"'' by [[Yaroslav Krestovsky]], "[[Chernaya River (Saint Petersburg)|Chernaya River]]" by [[Ivan Lavsky]], ''"Summer cottage"'' by [[Oleg Lomakin]], ''"In the Spring"'', ''"[[Koktebel]]"'' by [[Evsey Moiseenko]], ''"Autumn Park"'' by [[Alexei Mozhaev]], ''"Venice"'' by [[Andrei Mylnikov]], ''"A Winter"'' by [[Piotr Nazarov]], ''"A First snow"'' by [[Samuil Nevelshtein]], ''"[[Kizhi Pogost]]"'', ''"Wharf in [[Kizhi Pogost|Kizhi]]"'' by [[Dmitry Oboznenko]], ''"Little Bridge"'', ''"Autumn in the city"'', ''"Boats"'', ''"On the Volkhov River"'' by [[Sergei Ivanovich Osipov|Sergei Osipov]], ''"Spring"'' by [[Lia Ostrova]], ''"A Field"'', ''"Over the [[Dnieper River]]"'', ''"Walkway"'' by [[Filaret Pakun]], ''"Close to [[Yalu River]]"'' by [[Varlen Pen]], ''"In spring at the [[Summer Garden]]"'' by [[Boris Stepanovich Petrov|Boris Petrov]], ''"Spring etude"'', ''"House close to the road"'' by [[Nikolai Pozdneev]], ''"Old [[Petergof]]"'' by [[Stepan Privedentsev]], ''"Teracce"'' by [[Valentina Rakhina]], ''"A Path"'' by [[Maria Rudnitskaya]], ''"Street in [[Angarsk]]"'' by [[Vladimir Sakson]], ''"September on the Ural Mountains"'' by [[Ivan Savenko]], ''"After the rain"'' by [[Alexander Mikhailovich Semionov|Alexander Semionov]], ''"Spring theme"'', ''"Factory motive"'', ''"[[Fontanka River]]"'', ''"[[Trinity Cathedral, Saint Petersburg]]"'' by [[Arseny Semionov]], ''"[[Severodvinsk]]. Backwater"'' by [[Yuri Shablikin]], ''"Willow in bloom"'' by [[Boris Shamanov]], ''"Last Snow"'' by Vasily Sokolov, ''"In the Novgorod Province"'' by [[Alexander Stolbov]], ''"Winter landscape with small rugs"'' by [[Victor Teterin]], ''"First snow"'', ''"Cherry in bloom"'' by [[Nikolai Timkov]], ''"Abandoned gold fields"'' by [[Yuri Tulin]], ''"Venice"'', ''"A Winter"'', ''"[[Pskov]]"'' by [[Boris Ugarov]], ''"Autumn"'' by [[Ivan Varichev]], ''"[[Baykal Lake]]"'', ''"Snow goes"'', ''"After the rain"'', ''"Shore of [[Angara River]]"'' by [[Vecheslav Zagonek]], ''"[[Black Sea]]. Rocky shore"'', ''"Evening silence"'' by [[Elena Zhukova]], and others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1960 года. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1963.</ref>
'''Still life paintings''' were presented of ''"Irises"'', ''"Wildflower Bouquet"'' by [[Evgenia Antipova]], ''"Interior"'', ''"Still life"'' by [[Olga Bogaevskaya]], ''"Still life"'' by [[Gevork Kotiantz]], ''"Still life"'' by [[Mikhail Natarevich]], ''"Mushrooms"'' by [[Maria Rudnitskaya]], ''"In the garden"'' by [[Boris Shamanov]], ''"Fruits. Still life"'' by [[Elena Skuin]], ''"Still life with Melon"'' by Vasily Sokolov, ''"Snowdrops and lemons"'', ''"Rosehip"'' by [[Victor Teterin]], ''"A Winter Still life"'' by [[Rostislav Vovkushevsky]], and others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1960 года. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1963.</ref>
== Acknowledgment == Annual Exhibition of the Leningrad artists of 1960 was widely covered in press and in literature on Soviet fine art.<ref>''Художники народов СССР. Биобиблиографический словарь. Т. 1-4.''. М., Искусство, 1970-1995.</ref><ref>''Хроника узловых событий художественной жизни России 1960-1980-х годов'' // Time for Change. The Art of 1960-1985 in the Soviet Union. Saint Petersburg, State Russian Museum, 2006.</ref><ref>''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.''- Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. P.391.</ref><ref>[http://www.pv-gallery.ru/information/8480/?PAGE=1 ''Мочалов, Л. В.'' О чём говорит выставка // Творчество. Вып.2. М., 1961, с.4–6.]</ref>

[[File:Fischer und Frau.jpg|thumb|"The Fisherman and His Wife" illustration by [[Alexander Zick]]]] An '''anti-fairy tale''', also called '''anti-tale''', is a [[fairy tale]] which, unlike an ordinary one, has a tragic, rather than a [[happy ending]], with the antagonists winning and the protagonists losing at the end of the story. Whereas fairy tales paint a magical, utopian world, anti-fairy tales paint a dark world of nastiness and cruelty. Such stories incorporate [[Horror fiction|horror]], [[black comedy]], mean-spirited [[practical joke]]s on innocent characters, sudden and often cruel [[plot twist]]s, and biting [[satire]].<ref name=grenc>''The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Folktales and Fairy Tales: A-F'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=Jdx2fhPM1XIC&pg=PA50 article "Anti-fairy tale", p. 50]</ref><ref name=cada>Catriona McAra, David Calvin, ''Anti-Tales: The Uses of Disenchantment'', Cambridge Scholars Publishing, May 25, 2011, {{ISBN|1443830550}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=nQcrBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA4 p. 4]</ref> The term ({{lang-de|'Antimärchen'}}) was introduced by {{Interlanguage link multi|Andrè Jolles|de|3=Johannes Andreas Jolles}}<ref name=grenc/> in his ''Einfache Formen'' (1930).<ref>André Jolles: Einfache Formen. Legende, Sage, Mythe, Rätsel, Spruch, Kasus, Memorabile, Märchen, Witz. Niemeyer, Halle (Saale) 1930 (Forschungsinstitut für Neuere Philologie Leipzig: Neugermanistische Abteilung; 2) [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/joll001einf01_01/joll001einf01_01_0008.php p. 242].</ref>
Examples of anti-fairy tales include "[[The Fisherman and His Wife]]" and "[[The Swineherd]]".<ref name=grenc/> The term is also used to refer to remakes of traditional "happy" fairy tales into "unhappy" ones.<ref name=cada/> The ''[[Shrek (franchise)|Shrek]]'' film series, which parodies and satirises fairy tales, includes several elements of anti-fairy tales such as the deaths of heroic characters and [[toilet humour|scatalogical humour]].
==See also== *[[Anti-hero]] *[[Antinovel]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *[[Lutz Röhrich]], ''Märchen mit schlechtem Ausgang" ("Fairy Tales with Bad Ending"), In: ''Hessische Blätterfür Volkskunde''. 49-50 (1958) 236-248
[[Category:Fairy tales]]
{{Lit-genre-stub}}

{{Lead too short|date=August 2015}} '''Art Jewelry Forum (AJF)''' is a nonprofit international organization founded in 1997 that advocates for the field of contemporary [[art jewelry]] through education, discourse, publications, grants, and awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/about-ajf|title=About AJF|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref>
==Publications== Art Jewelry Forum publishes online articles as well as in print books. AJF’s online articles cover historical pieces and movements, theoretical interpretations of work, and exhibition reviews. Contributors for the online articles include staff writers as well as professionals in the field. Printed books from Art Jewelry Forum include ''Geography'' (exhibition catalog), ''AJF Best of Interviews'', and ''Show and Tales''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/bookstore/ajf-publications%7ctitle=Bookstore%7cwork=artjewelryforum.org%7ctitle=Bookstore%7cwork=artjewelryforum.org|title=Bookstore|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref> Art jewelry Forum also initiated and funded the publication of ''Contemporary Jewelry in Perspective'' by Lark Crafts.
The exhibition catalog ''Geography'' was Art Jewelry Forum's first publication in 2011. ''Geography'' was printed in conjunction with an exhibition of the same name that was presented at SOFA Chicago 2011 and at the [[Society of North American Goldsmiths]] conference in Seattle of 2011.
Art Jewelry Forum worked with Lark Crafts,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larkcrafts.com/jewelry-beading/announcing-contemporary-jewelry-in-perspective/|title=Announcing "Contemporary Jewelry in Perspective" « Lark Crafts|work=larkcrafts.com}}</ref> a subsidiary of [[Sterling Publishing]], in 2013 to publish ''Contemporary Jewelry in Perspective''. ''Contemporary Jewelry in Perspective'' is broken into three sections "the first exploring what kind of thing contemporary jewelry is, the second exploring its history, and the third exploring opportunities and challenges for the field".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://craftcouncil.org/magazine/article/assume-nothing|title=Assume Nothing|work=craftcouncil.org}}</ref> [[Bruce Metcalf]] reviews that within these sections "There are two themes that run throughout the book. One is that studio jewelry should be critical. The other is that the most fertile territory for the present-day practitioner is in the realm of the hybrid."<ref>Metcalf, Bruce. "Under the Covers: Contemporary Jewelry in Perspective". ''Metalsmith Magazine'' March, 2014. Volume 34 Number 2. Pg. 16-17. Print.</ref>
''AJF Best of Interviews'' was published in 2014 by Art Jewelry Forum. ''AJF Best of Interviews'' "corrals some of the site’s most interesting content: interviews with jewelry makers and others central to the field. Taking part in the 20 lively conversations are makers such as Lola Brooks, [[Tanel Veenre]], and Jamie Bennett; dealers such as Sienna Patti; curators such as Bruce Pepich and Ursula Ilse-Neuman; and jewelry aficionados such as [[Madeleine Albright]]... The focus is on intelligent questions and the voices of the interviewees – captured in fresh, informal exchanges that will captivate lovers of art jewelry"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://craftcouncil.org/magazine/article/fresh-perspectives|title=Fresh Perspectives|work=craftcouncil.org}}</ref> writes Monica Moses, editor in chief at the ''American Craft Magazine'' published by the [[American Craft Council]].
''Show and Tales'' published by Art Jewelry Forum in 2015 and was released in Munich in conjunction with the annual Schmuck fair. ''Show and Tales'' focuses on exhibition making in regards to jewelry, making it the first ever publication on the topic.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ''Show and Tales'' is broken into three sections that cover historical landmark exhibitions of jewelry, challenges in curating craft and jewelry, and exhibition reviews. It contains essays by Glenn Adamson (USA), David Beytelmann (AR), Susan Cummins (USA), {{Interlanguage link multi|Liesbeth den Besten|nl}} (NL), Monica Gaspar (ES), Toni Greenbaum (USA), Marthe Le Van (USA), Benjamin Lignel (FR), Kellie Riggs (USA), Damian Skinner (NZ), {{Interlanguage link multi|Jorunn Veiteberg|no}} (NO), Namita Wiggers (USA), among others.
==Exhibitions== To date, Art Jewelry Forum has produced one exhibition titled ''Geography'', which was shown in 2011 at SOFA Chicago<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sofaexpo.com/chicago/essays/2011/geography|title=Geography: An Exhibition Organized by Art Jewelry Forum|work=sofaexpo.com}}</ref> and at the [[Society of North American Goldsmiths]] conference in Seattle in 2011.<ref name="snagmetalsmith.org">http://www.snagmetalsmith.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/2011-Conference-Program-Book-Final.pdf</ref> ''Geography'' was a thematic exhibition focusing on the scientific view of physical geography, the relational cultural geography, and the effects of natural surroundings on artists.<ref name="snagmetalsmith.org"/> ''Geography'' was curated by Susan Cummins and Mike Holmes and features over seventy pieces<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2011/11/01/sofa-chicago-art-show|title=SOFA Chicago Art Show|work=Chicago Tonight - WTTW}}</ref> of jewelry from a wide array of international artists:
Fran Allison, Talya Baharal, Agelio Batle, Suzanne Beautyman, {{Interlanguage link multi|David Bielander|nl}}, Alexander Blank, {{Interlanguage link multi|Iris Bodemer|nl}}, Angela Bubash, Eric Burris, Suzanne Carlsen, Attai Chen, Jim Cotter, {{Interlanguage link multi|Willemijn de Greef|nl}}, Bettina Dittlmann, Georg Dobler, {{Interlanguage link multi|Iris Eichenberg|nl}}, {{Interlanguage link multi|Jantje Fleischhut|nl}}, Karen Gilbert, Gabrielle Gould, Mielle Harvey, Stefan Heuser, Rory Hooper, Marian Hosking, Sergey Jiventin, Soyeon Kim, Jenny Klemming, Brooke Marks Swanson, Sharon Massey, Christine Matthias, {{Interlanguage link multi|Fritz Maierhofer|de}}, Malaika Najem, Annelies Planteydt, Alan Preston, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ramon Puig i Cuyàs|ca}}, Tina Rath, Miriam Rowe, Deborah Rudolph, Estela Saez, Dana Seachuga, Nolia Shakti, [[Deganit Stern Schocken]], [[Joyce Scott]], Helen Shirk, Despo Sophocleous, Cynthia Toops, Julia Turner, Tarja Tuupanen, Sally von Bargen, [[Lisa Walker (jeweller)|Lisa Walker]], [[Areta Wilkinson]], Francis Willemstijn, Andrea Williams, [[Nancy Worden]]<ref name="snagmetalsmith.org"/>
==Grants== Art Jewelry Forum awards grants in three categories; Emerging Artist Award, Exhibition Award, and Speakers and Writers Awards.
===Emerging Artist Award===
The Emerging Artist Award is a prestigious<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gia.edu/library-design-competition|title=Design Competitions|work=gia.edu}}</ref> annual juried award of emerging artists who make wearable art jewelry with a prize of $7,500USD.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/ajf-artist-award-emerging-artist-guidelines|title=AJF Artist Award Emerging Artist Guidelines|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref>
Past winners include: *2014-Seulgi Kwon<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kwonseulgi.com/english.html|title=English|work=kwonseulgi.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jckonline.com/2014/12/11/seulgi-kwon-wins-2014-ajf-artist-award-0|title=Seulgi Kwon Wins 2014 AJF Artist Award|work=JCK Magazine}}</ref> *2013- Sooyeon Kim<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sooyeonkim.com/index.php/profile/english|title=English|work=sooyeonkim jewelry}}</ref> *2012- Noon Passama Sanpatchayapong<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noonpassama.com/index.php?/cv/|title=CV : Noon Passama|work=noonpassama.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accessoriesmagazine.com/60096/art-jewelry-forum-awards-creativity-and-promise#.VaFJSe1Viko|title=Art Jewelry Forum Awards Creativity and Promise|work=Accessories Magazine}}</ref> *2011-Farrah Al-Dujaili<ref>{{cite web|url=http://farrahal-dujaili.blogspot.com/p/cv.html|title=Farrah Al-Dujaili|work=farrahal-dujaili.blogspot.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.schoolofjewellery.co.uk/news/archive/2012/01/10/emerging_artist_award|title=School of Jewellery|work=schoolofjewellery.co.uk}}</ref> *2010 Agnes Larsson<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agneslarsson.com/#category3%7ctitle=www.agneslarsson.com%7cwork=agneslarsson.com|title=www.agneslarsson.com|work=agneslarsson.com}}</ref> *2009- Sharon Massey<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sharon-massey.com/cv.html |title=cv |work=sharon-massey.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709115817/http://sharon-massey.com/cv.html |archivedate=2015-07-09 }}</ref> *2008- Masumi Kataoka<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masumikataoka.com/#!cv/c21e2|title=Masumi Kataoka, contemporary Jewelry|work=Masumi Kataoka, contemporary Jewelry}}</ref> *2007- Andrea Janosik<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/grants/emerging-artist-award-recipients/2007-andrea-janosik|title=2007: Andrea Janosik - Art Jewelry Forum|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref> *2006- Natalya Pinchuk<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/grants/emerging-artist-award-recipients/2006-natalya-pinchuk|title=2006: Natalya Pinchuk - Art Jewelry Forum|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref>
===Exhibition Award===
The Exhibition Award aims to financially assist with exhibitions and catalogs that focus on [[art jewelry]]. Unlike the annual Artist Award, the Exhibition Award applications are rolling; the Exhibition Award is based on merit of the proposed project, and Art Jewelry Forums annual funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/grants/exhibitions-award-recipients|title=Exhibitions Award Recipients|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref>
Past support of the Exhibition Award has gone to: *2012- ''Shift: Contemporary Makers That Define, Expand and Contradict The Field of Art Jewelry'', Grunwald Gallery of Art, [[Indiana University]], for exhibition support<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~grunwald/exhibitions.php?pid=shift%7ctitle=Shift%7cwork=indiana.edu|title=EXHIBIT ARCHIVE|work=indiana.edu}}</ref> *2011- ''Geography'', Art Jewelry Forum, for catalog publication<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/grants/exhibitions-award-recipients/2011-art-jewelry-forum|title=2011: Art Jewelry Forum - Art Jewelry Forum|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref> *2010- ''Atelier Janiyé and the Legacy of Miye Matsukata'', [[Fuller Craft Museum]], for catalog publication<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accessoriesmagazine.com/4290/fuller-craft-museum-wins-art-jewelry-forum-award#.VZ1Fwu1Viko|title=Fuller Craft Museum Wins Art Jewelry Forum Award|work=Accessories Magazine}}</ref><ref name="boston.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/yourtown/boston/downtown/articles/2011/01/31/fuller_craft_traces_studio_jewelers_work_and_legacy/|title=Fuller Craft traces studio jeweler’s work and legacy|work=Boston.com}}</ref><ref name="boston.com"/> *2009- ''[[Lisa Gralnick]]: The Gold Standard'', [[Bellevue Arts Museum]], for exhibition support<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/press-releases/art-jewelry-forum-announces-grant-award-bellevue-arts-museum-and-miami-university-ohi|title=Art Jewelry Forum Announces Grant Award to Bellevue Arts Museum and Miami University of Ohio - Art Jewelry Forum|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellevuearts.org/exhibitions/past/2010/lisa_gralnick.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712180804/http://www.bellevuearts.org/exhibitions/past/2010/lisa_gralnick.html |archivedate=2015-07-12 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allartnews.com/lisa-gralnick-the-gold-standard-at-bellevue-arts-museum/|title=Lisa Gralnick: The Gold Standard at Bellevue Arts Museum|work=All Art News}}</ref> *2009- ''Adornment and Excess:Jewelry in the 21st Century'', [[Miami University Art Museum]], for exhibition support<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journal-news.com/news/news/local/jewelry-exhibit-now-open-at-mu-art-museum-1/nNbRB/|title=Jewelry exhibit now open at MU Art Museum|work=journal-news.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://arts.muohio.edu/art-museum/exhibitions/past-exhibitions/adornment-and-excess|title=Adornment and Excess: Jewelry in the 21st Century|work=muohio.edu}}</ref> *2008- ''Decorative Resurgence'', Rowan University, for catalog publication<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rowan.edu/artgallery/exhibitions/index.cfm?id=34|title=Rowan University Art Gallery|work=rowan.edu}}</ref> *2007- ''Women of Metal'', University of Wisconsin at Whitewater, for exhibition support<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uww.edu/alumni/enews/story_one.html|title=Artwork of prominent women metalsmiths on display at Crossman Gallery Sept. 9-Oct. 18|work=uww.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uww.edu/news/archive/2008-09-women-of-metal|title=Artwork of prominent women metalsmiths on display at Crossman Gallery|work=uww.edu}}</ref> *2006- ''For Zymrina, A Prostitute of Pompeii'', [[Houston Museum of Fine Arts]], acquisition of Keith Lewis’ Neckpiece<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/grants/exhibitions-award-recipients/2006-houston-museum-fine-arts|title=2006: Houston Museum of Fine Arts - Art Jewelry Forum|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref> *2005- Craft Emergency Relief Fund<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/grants/exhibitions-award-recipients/2005-craft-emergency-relief-fund|title=2005: Craft Emergency Relief Fund - Art Jewelry Forum|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref>
===Speakers and Writers Award===
Art Jewelry Forum awards the Speaker and Writers Award to individuals who are critically engaged in the field. Most often the award is granted to help cover expenses of speakers and panelists at the annual Sculptural Objects and Functional Art (SOFA) NY and the SOFA Chicago fairs, and the annual [[Society of North American Goldsmiths]] conference.<ref name="artjewelryforum.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/grants/speakers-writers-award-recipients|title=Speakers & Writers Award Recipients|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref>
Past recipients of the Speakers and Writers Award are:
*2012- [[Kiff Slemmons]], ''More Than One to Make One'', lecture, SOFA Chicago<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artslant.com/chi/events/show/241192-sofa-chicago-2012---lecrure-series|title=ArtSlant - November 2nd, 2012 - November 3rd, 2012, SOFA Chicago,|work=ArtSlant}}</ref> *2012- Garth Clark, ''Who's Your Daddy'', keynote lecture, [[Society of North American Goldsmiths]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.e-digitaleditions.com/i/64518-2012-conference-program/19|title=SNAG Conference - 2012 Conference Program|work=e-digitaleditions.com}}</ref> *2012, Ursula Ilse-Neuman, ''The Transcendent Jewelry of Margaret De Patta: Vision in Motion'', lecture, SOFA NY<ref>http://www.sofaexpo.com/epress/pressroom/ny12/releases/SOFA_NY_2012_Lecture_Release.pdf</ref> *2011- Contributing Writers: Jillian Moore, Gabriel Craig, commissioning of articles for Art Jewelry Forum *2011- Davra Taragin, {{Interlanguage link multi|Iris Eichenberg|nl}}, Seth Papac, Gemma Draper, ''Monomater'', panel discussion, SOFA Chicago<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sofaexpo.com/chicago/essays/2011/continuing-the-cranbrook-vision|title=Continuing the Cranbrook Vision: "Monomater"|work=sofaexpo.com}}</ref> *2011- Damien Skinner, ''All the World Over: The Global Ambitions of Contemporary Jewelry'', lecture, [[Society of North American Goldsmiths]]<ref name="snagmetalsmith.org"/> *2011- Jeannine Falino, ''For People Who Are Slightly Mad'', lecture, SOFA NY<ref name="artjewelryforum.org"/>
==Board and select staff== Susan Cummins is the founder and current board chair of AJF. She is also the director for the Rotasa Foundation,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cca.edu/about/president/board/scummins%7ctitle=Trustees%7cwork=cca.edu|title=Trustees|work=cca.edu}}</ref> and previously owned and operated Susan Cummins Gallery for eighteen years until its closing in 2002.
{{Interlanguage link multi|Liesbeth den Besten|nl}} is a board member and contributing writer for AJF. Besten graduated with a PhD in Art History from the University of Amsterdam in 1985. Besten's research and writing focuses on jewelry. Along with writing articles for AJF, Besten has written ''On Jewellery, A Compendium of International Contemporary Art Jewelery'', numerous catalogs, and essays in ''Show and Tales'', ''Art Jewelry Forum's Best of Interviews'', and ''Contemporary Jewelry in Perspective''.
[[Tanel Veenre]] is a board member of AJF. Veere graduated from the Estonian Academy of the Arts in Metal in 2005 where he is currently a professor.
Benjamin Lignel is the editor and writer for AJF. Lignel studied Philosophy and Art History at [[New York University]]. He later went on to study Furniture Design in London. Lignel is also a co-founder of la garantie, association pour le bijou, and a member of [[Think Tank]] since 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://klimt02.net/jewellers/benjamin-lignel|title=Klimt02.net Benjamin Lignel|work=klimt02.net}}</ref>
Other board members and staff include: Linda Peshkin, Marion Fulk, Sienna Patti, Raissa Bump, Bonnie Levine, Doug Bucci, Sharon Berman, Susan Kempkin, Bella Neyman, Sofia Björkman, Jorge Manilla, Rebekah Frank, Nathalie Mornu, Kevin Murray, and Dina Noto<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artjewelryforum.org/board-members|title=Board and Staff|work=artjewelryforum.org}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} An '''art blog''' is a common type of [[blog]] that comments on art. More recently, as with other types of blogs, some art blogs have taken on 'web 2.0' social networking features. Art blogs that adopt this sort of change can develop to become a source of information on art events (listings and maps), a way to share information and images, or virtual meeting ground. Art blogs entries cover different topics, from art critiques and commentary to insider art world gossip, auction results, art news, personal essays, portfolios, interviews, artists’ journals, art marketing advice and artist biographies. Some artists use art blogs as a form of new media art project. Art blogs may also serve as a forum to reach out to anybody interested in art — be it painting, sculpture, print making, creative photography, video art, conceptual art or new media. In this way, they may be visited not only for the practitioners of different forms of art, but also collectors, connoisseurs, and critics. ==Mainstream media== In 2011, art critic [[Brian Sherwin]] interviewed art critic Mat Gleason of [[Coagula Art Journal]] for Faso.com's FineArtViews blog. The interview between Sherwin and Gleason focused on [[contemporary art]] criticism and the role of art blog’s in present-day [[art criticism]] among other issues. Gleason suggested to Sherwin that art blogs and the development of new media have become a "''blow''" to traditional print art magazines. Gleason and Sherwin also discussed how [[bloggers]] form a "''pack mentality''" based on region and perceived significance.[http://faso.com/fineartviews/27987/fineartviews-interview-mat-gleason-art-critic-and-founder-of-coagula-art-journal "FineArtViews Interview: Mat Gleason -- Art Critic and Founder of Coagula Art Journal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111218141116/http://faso.com/fineartviews/27987/fineartviews-interview-mat-gleason-art-critic-and-founder-of-coagula-art-journal |date=18 December 2011 }}, Faso.com - FineArtViews. Retrieved 7 January 2012.[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/26/fineartsviews-interviews-_n_828719.html "FineArtViews Interviews Mat Gleason, Art Critic/Founder of Coagula"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420061624/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/26/fineartsviews-interviews-_n_828719.html |date=20 April 2012 }}, Huffington Post. Retrieved 7 January 2012. On April 28, 2009, Art Connect produced an in-depth interview by Peter Cowling for [[Art Connect]] and Jessica Palmer of [[Bioephemera]]. The interview, titled It is not Really Bloggers vs. Journalists, You Know,Cowling, Peter and Palmer, Jessica, "It is not Really Bloggers vs. Journalists, You Know", April 2009 {{cite web|url=http://www.loveart-gallery.com/art-blog-reviews/2009/04/27/extraordinary-art-blogs-series-part-seven-it-is-not-really-bloggers-vs-journalists-you-know |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701133911/http://www.loveart-gallery.com/art-blog-reviews/2009/04/27/extraordinary-art-blogs-series-part-seven-it-is-not-really-bloggers-vs-journalists-you-know/ |archivedate=1 July 2009 |df=dmy }} pointed to five trends that were shaping the communication and discussion of art on the internet, and that the real picture was much bigger than just the bloggers vs. journalists that had been discussed to date. These five points were: * Media convergence will continue to improve consumer choice, providing a better match between desire and availability. * Content producers are just that. Consumers care less about how and where they can get the content they want. What they do consistently care about is the quality of the content, and whether the content is produced to their timescales. * The content producer-to-content consumer relationship is changing. Requests for feedback and further debate have been partially overtaken by things like conversations, and further fragmentation will certainly occur. * Information technology and systems, provided as commodity (pay-as-you-go) services. Such services range from processing and storage, through to credit card processing and super-fast content delivery. * The economic downrun. On January 8, 2009, Regina Hackett, art critic of the [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]], noted in her article Art Blogs Hit Wikipedia Hackett, Regina, "Art Blogs Hit Wikipedia." ''Seattle Post-Intelligencer'', January 2009. {{cite web |url=http://blog.seattlepi.nwsource.com/art/archives/159041.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-19 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720231949/http://blog.seattlepi.nwsource.com/art/archives/159041.asp |archivedate=20 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} that commercially run, mainstream media supported, art blogs face issues of acceptance among the independent art blogging community. On January 7, 2009, ''[[The Village Voice]]'' art critic Martha Schwendener suggests that art blogs have helped shape a more laissez-faire climate for art writing. "Art blogs have created a new, largely unedited, admirably 'unprofessional'—hence, democratic—venue for people to speak their minds, gossip, or theorize about art."Schwendener, Martha, "What Crisis? Some Promising Futures for Art Criticism." ''The Village Voice'', January 2009. {{cite web |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2009-01-07/art/what-crisis-some-promising-futures-for-art-criticism/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116123956/http://www.villagevoice.com/2009-01-07/art/what-crisis-some-promising-futures-for-art-criticism |archivedate=16 January 2009 |df=dmy-all }} In September 2008, the ''[[Brooklyn Rail]]'' contributor [[James Kalm]] produced an article titled "Virtually Overwhelmed.".[http://www.brooklynrail.org/2008/09/artseen/brooklyn-dispatches-virtually-overwhelmed Kalm, James, "Virtually Overwhelmed." ''Brooklyn Rail''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105114244/http://www.brooklynrail.org/2008/09/artseen/brooklyn-dispatches-virtually-overwhelmed |date=5 January 2009 }} A practicing artist and video blogger himself, Kalm has this to say about art blogs, "The art blogosphere is a work in progress, and you’ve got to be vigilant of hidden agendas. As with anything online, take it with a grain of salt. Have fun, speak out, but don’t let it cut too much into your studio time; you might end up in a twelve step-program." In the November 2007 issue of ''[[Art in America]]'', [[Peter Plagens]] contributed "Report from the Blogosphere: The New Grass Roots."Plagens, Peter, "Report from the Blogosphere: The New Grass Roots." ''Art in America'', November 2007. [http://madsilence.wordpress.com/2008/02/03/the-future-of-the-art-blog/] Plagens convened a round table of veteran art bloggers, who conversed via email on a range of questions, aimed at getting a better understanding of what art blogs were, how they were run, and their relationship with the mainstream media. In an October 2007 article for artnet Magazine, critic Charlie Finch suggested that art critiques and reviews by art bloggers are overrated and lengthy, and implied that the art blogging community was overly insular.Finch, Charlie, "A NOT-SO-VAST RIGHT-WING CONSPIRACY" ''artnet Magazine'', {{cite web |url=http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/finch/finch10-26-07.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418041306/http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/finch/finch10-26-07.asp |archivedate=18 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} The article includes several ''ad hominen'' arguments against specific art bloggers, and ventures the opinion that art blogs "have no readers". In the January 2005 issue of ''[[Art in America]]'',Rubinstein, Rafael, "Art in the Blogoshere." ''Art in America'', "Front Page," January 2005. {{cite web |url=http://www.firstpulseprojects.com/frontpageaia.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080807172818/http://www.firstpulseprojects.com/frontpageaia.pdf |archivedate=7 August 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Raphael Rubinstein mentioned several blogs in the magazine's "Front Page" section, where he penned a brief, annotated survey of 12 art blogs that he found "to be worth regular visits.". Rubinstein opined that "art-related blogs" had not, at the time, become as consequential as blogs in other fields such as poetry or politics. == Academia == In December 2008, the art blog [[Maurice Benayoun|The Dump]],{{cite web|url=http://www.the-dump.net/|title=The-dump|author=|date=|website=www.the-dump.net|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180212143100/http://the-dump.net/|archivedate=12 February 2018|df=dmy-all}} where the new-media artist [[Maurice Benayoun]] dumped hundreds of undone art projects, was the first to become a doctorate thesis in art and art science in and of itself: ''Artistic Intentions at Work, Hypothesis for Committing Art'' Université Pantheon Sorbonne (December 6, 2008) This PhD was directed by Prof. Anne-Marie Duguet. Jury : Prof. [[Hubertus von Amelunxen]], [[Louis Bec]], artist, Prof. [[Derrick de Kerckhove]], and Prof. Jean da Silva.
In May 2010, ''The Dump – Recycling of Thoughts'', a contemporary art exhibition curated by Agnieszka Kulazińska at Laznia Art Center ([[Gdańsk]], [[Poland]]) presented 9 artists whose works were derived from ''The Dump'' blog project list.{{cite web|url=http://www.laznia.pl/index.php?idDzial=9&idWpis=525|title=Centrum Sztuki Współczesnej Łaźnia|first=Studio eMart|last=biuro@studioemart.pl|date=|website=www.laznia.pl|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314081644/http://laznia.pl/index.php?iddzial=9&idwpis=525|archivedate=14 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} ==Other coverage == Other coverage of art blogs includes interviews of art bloggers, reviews of art blog site, and recommendations of favourite sites. Art Connect has produced around 90 reviews of art blogs, and undertakes interviews with art bloggers.[http://www.loveart-gallery.com/art-blog-reviews/ Art Connect review of art blogs] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124135259/http://www.loveart-gallery.com/art-blog-reviews/ |date=24 January 2009 }} The [[Courtauld Institute of Art]], in London, maintains a list of recommended art blogs .List of art blogs recommended by the Courtauld Institute of Art, London, {{cite web |url=http://www.courtauld.ac.uk/booklibrary/collections_services/links.shtml/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029201701/http://www.courtauld.ac.uk/booklibrary/collections_services/links.shtml |archivedate=29 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Directories such as Yahoo! Directory and BlogCatalog maintain a list of user submitted art blogs. ==List of notable art blogs== *''[[Mira Schor|A Year of Positive Thinking]]'' {{cite web|url=http://ayearofpositivethinking.com/|title=A Year of Positive Thinking - Mira Schor|author=|date=|website=ayearofpositivethinking.com|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707202156/http://ayearofpositivethinking.com/ |archivedate=7 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} is published by artist and activist [[Mira Schor]], "a cheerful postscript" to her book of essays on art, culture and politics called ''A Decade of Negative Thinking''. *''[[Paddy Johnson|Art F City]]'" founded by Paddy Johnson, this officially non-profit art blog covers new art in New York. At the NYTimes, Holland Cotter named AFC as a blog that "combines criticism, reporting, political activism and gossip on an almost-24-hour news cycle."Holland Cotter,"Lost in the Gallery-Industrial Complex," New York Times, January 17, 2014.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/19/arts/design/holland-cotter-looks-at-money-in-art.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-02-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729010753/https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/19/arts/design/holland-cotter-looks-at-money-in-art.html |archivedate=29 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} *''[[Maurice Benayoun|The Dump]]'' by the French new media artist [[Maurice Benayoun]] delivering hundreds of undone art projects [http://www.cgw.com/Print.aspx?Page=/Publications/CGW/2009/Volume-32-Issue-4-Apr-2009-/Without-Bounds.aspx] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716201324/http://www.cgw.com/Print.aspx?Page=%2FPublications%2FCGW%2F2009%2FVolume-32-Issue-4-Apr-2009-%2FWithout-Bounds.aspx |date=16 July 2011 }} ''Without Bounds'' by Barbara Robertson in CGW volume 32 issue 4 April 2009 * ''[[Hyperallergic]]'', founded by the art critic Hrag Vartanian and his husband Veken Gueyikian in October 2009. The site describes itself as a "forum for serious, playful and radical thinking."{{cite web|url=http://hyperallergic.com/|title=Hyperallergic|author=|date=|website=Hyperallergic|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323204905/https://hyperallergic.com/|archivedate=23 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} *''[[NEWSgrist]]'',{{cite web|url=http://newsgrist.typepad.com/|title=NEWSgrist - where spin is art|author=|date=|website=newsgrist.typepad.com|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323152450/http://newsgrist.typepad.com/|archivedate=23 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} maintained by artist [[Joy Garnett]], began in March 2000 as an e-zine devoted to the politics of art and culture in the digital age. For four years it was distributed entirely by email subscription. *''[[PORT]]'', co-founded in 2005 by Jennifer Armbrust and [[Jeff Jahn]] (who still maintains the site) PORT{{cite web|url=http://www.portlandart.net/|title=PORT: portlandart.net - Portland art + news + reviews|author=|date=|website=www.portlandart.net|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171121025150/http://www.portlandart.net/|archivedate=21 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} focuses on critical content related to the Portland art scene. PORT describes itself as "dedicated to catalyzing critical discussion and disseminating information about art as lensed through Portland, Oregon." In the November 2007 Art in America roundtable Plagens described PORT as, "the closest thing to the virtues (paid critics, office help, etc.) of a print art magazine on the Internet...." In 2007 [[Tyler Green (journalist)|Tyler Green]] described PORT as, "The undisputed champ of the regional art blogs." on Off Center, the Walker Art Center's blog. *''The Silo''{{cite web|url=http://thesilo.raphaelrubinstein.com/|title=The Silo by Raphael Rubinstein|author=|date=|website=thesilo.raphaelrubinstein.com|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322094709/http://thesilo.raphaelrubinstein.com/|archivedate=22 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} is maintained by art critic and poet Raphael Rubinstein. A revisionist “dictionary” of contemporary art aimed at challenging existing accounts of art since 1960 and to offer a fresh look at some well-known artists, The Silo was originally funded by an Andy Warhol/Creative Capital Arts Writing Grant. *''[[Two Coats of Paint]],''[http://www.twocoatsofpaint.com/ Two Coats of Paint] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140705141241/http://www.twocoatsofpaint.com/ |date=5 July 2014 }} founded by Sharon Butler in 2007, is dedicated to contemporary painting and related subjects. Received a Creative Capital/Warhol Foundation Arts Writing Grant in 2013-14. *''[[Fruit Carving Art Blog]],''{{cite web|url=http://www.fruitcarvinglessons.co.uk/|title=Fruit Carving Lessons - Fruit Carving Classes - Vegetable Carving - FruitCarvingLessons.co.uk|author=|date=|website=www.fruitcarvinglessons.co.uk|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171014172335/http://www.fruitcarvinglessons.co.uk/|archivedate=14 October 2017|df=dmy-all}} founded by Kelly in 2007 *''[[Wooster Collective]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.woostercollective.com/|title=Wooster Collective|author=|date=|website=Wooster Collective|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151027052728/http://woostercollective.com/|archivedate=27 October 2015|df=dmy-all}} was founded in 2001. This site focuses on ephemeral art placed on streets in cities around the world. Updated by Marc and Sara Schiller, the site also offers podcasting with music and interviews featuring street artists. *''[[In Terms Of]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.in-terms-of.com/|title=In Terms Of|author=|date=|website=In Terms Of|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171221010952/http://www.in-terms-of.com/|archivedate=21 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}, created by the art critic and historian Christopher Howard, first came online in 2011. The site publishes reviews of lectures, panels, interviews, conferences, and other live speaking engagements in the visual arts. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Art blogs}} {{Blog topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Art Blog}} [[Category:Blogs by subject]] [[Category:Blogospheres]] [[Category:Art websites]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} '''Art in Dubai''' is an emerging activity in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. New galleries such as [[Carbon 12 Dubai]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://carbon12dubai.com/ |title=Carbon12 – Contemporary art in Dubai, UAE |publisher=CARBON 12 DUBAI |date=2013-08-13 |accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref> [[art fairs]], artists, art patrons and collectors have grown in number.
==Art fairs== Dubai hosts several international art fairs, including [[Art Dubai]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artdubai.ae/|title=Home - Art Dubai|last=Dubai|first=Art|website=Art Dubai|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-28}} </ref> and [[Sikka Art Fair]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Bastikiya Art Fair |url=http://www.bastakiyaartfair.com/ |accessdate=24 May 2010}}</ref> Art Dubai takes place every March at Madinat Jumeirah. It was the nation's first contemporary art fair. The 2009 fair hosted nearly seventy galleries from the Middle East, Asia, Europe, North and South America, North Africa and Australia. In addition, artists' projects were initiated, including the launch of The Abraaj Group Art Prize and Global Art Forum:3.
==Media==
The arts in Dubai and the surrounding Gulf and Middle East arts scene are covered in magazines, film, radio and online.
===Magazines=== *''[[Vision (magazine)|Vision]]'' is a Dubai-based Magazine presenting Dubai’s perspective on art, music, culture, business and life in the Emirate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.falconandassociates.ae/en/our-work/article/vision-magazine|title=Vision Magazine|work=Falcon and Associates|access-date=2018-05-28|language=en}}</ref> *''Brownbook'', based in Dubai, is an urban lifestyle guide focusing on art, design, and travel across the Middle East and North Africa.<ref>{{cite web |title=Brownbook Magazine Homepage |url=http://www.brownbookmag.com/ |accessdate=24 May 2010}}</ref> *''Canvas'' is an international bi-monthly magazine dedicated to art and culture from the Middle East and Arab world.<ref>{{cite web |title=Canvas Online |url=http://www.canvasonline.com/ |accessdate=24 May 2010}}</ref> *''[[Bidoun]]'' covers art and culture from the Middle East.<ref>* [http://bidoun.com/bdn/ Bidoun] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524220805/http://bidoun.com/bdn/ |date=24 May 2010 }} </ref> * ''[[Harpers Bazaar]] Art Arabia'' was launched in early 2012 and has now become a bi-monthly, dedicated to contemporary art from the Middle East and the Arab World. * ''Contemporary Art Practices'' is another journal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.contemporarypractices.net/|title=Contemporary Practices|website=www.contemporarypractices.net|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref> *''[[Selections Magazine]]'' is a bi-monthly portfolio of arts, culture, design, and style from the Arab world and beyond.<ref>http://www.selectionsthemagazine.com/</ref>
===Film===
Director Katy Chang's ''[[Glitter Dust: Finding Art in Dubai]]'' is a documentary about cultural integration and immigration through the lens of the Dubai art scene.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glitter Dust |url=http://www.glitterdust.mer-chan.com/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120917200353/http://www.glitterdust.mer-chan.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 September 2012 |accessdate=24 May 2010 }}</ref> The film features Dubai-based artists Shaqayeq Arabi, Vivek Premachandran (UBIK) and Hazem Mahdi, with commentary from art historian Marcelo Lima and others. Chang runs the Twitter feed, Art in Dubai, covering Middle Eastern art and reviews.
===Radio===
Siobhan Leydon's weekly lunchtime [[Dubai Eye 103.8]] radio show ''The Edge'' covers art, culture, architecture, design, world music, books, theatre etc., in the region and internationally.<ref>{{cite web |title=Shioban Live |url=http://dubaieye1038.com/96/siobhan-live/ |accessdate=24 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100528110658/http://dubaieye1038.com/96/siobhan-live/| archivedate= 28 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Culture of Dubai]] *[[Dubai Culture|Dubai Culture and Arts Authority]] *[[DUCTAC]] *[[Tashkeel Dubai]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.designdaysdubai.ae/ Design Days Dubai] * [http://glitterdustfilm.com/ Glitter Dust] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121115091532/http://www.dubaicalendar.ae/en/event/events/art-dubai-2013.html Art Dubai 2013 – Dubai Events Official Listing]
[[Category:Emirati art|Dubai]] [[Category:Culture in Dubai]]
{{art-stub}}

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=March 2013}} '''Arts Initiative Tokyo''' (AIT) a not-for-profit independent collective of [[curator]]s and [[art]] [[Management|administrator]]s based in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. It is especially concerned with [[contemporary art]].
==Information== It was founded in 2001 by six curators and arts administrators: Yuko Ozawa (Director), Yoko Miyahara ([[Mori Art Museum]]), Keisuke Ozawa (independent curator, Associate Director Art Fair Tokyo, lecturer Joshibi), Yasu Nakamori (Curator, Lecturer, Houston), Fumihiko Sumitomo (independent curator) and Roger McDonald (independent curator, lecturer [[Meiji University]], Joshibi).
AIT was registered as a non profit organisation (NPO) by the City of Tokyo in 2002.
==Initiatives== Its main initiatives are: Tokyo's first systematic artist in residence program partnering with organisations such as [[IASPIS]], [[Asialink]] and FRAME, and an independent contemporary art school called MAD.
==Artist Residence Program== The artist in residence program has hosted many artists and curators from around the world. Most stay in AIT's refurbished traditional Japanese store-house in Yukigaya, Tokyo. Most residencies is for three months, although curators tend to come for one month. The residency program is not an open application one, instead operating on a partnership model, with various international arts organisations and Japanese Foundations.
MAD is an acronym for Making Art Different. It offered the first course in curatorial studies in Japan in 2001. In 2011 MAD ceased offering courses and instead initiated a flexible, self-selecting system in which students purchase numbers of lectures to create their own course of study. 111 lectures are offered in 2011.
AIT does not hold a permanent exhibition space, rather working out of an office/ classroom in the area [[Daikanyama]] of Tokyo.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{art-org-stub}}
==External links== * [http://www.a-i-t.net/ Website] * [http://www.a-i-t.net/eg/mad_e/courses_e.html English information]
[[Category:Japanese contemporary art]] [[Category:Asian Cultural Council grantees]] [[Category:Organizations based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2001]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Japan]]

{{other uses}} "'''Bookland'''" is the informal name for the [[Unique Country Code]] (UCC) prefix allocated in the 1980s for [[European Article Number]] (EAN) identifiers of published [[book]]s, regardless of country of origin, so that the EAN [[namespace]] can catalogue books by [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN]] rather than maintaining a redundant parallel numbering system. In other words, Bookland is a fictitious country that exists solely in EAN for the purposes of non-geographically cataloguing books in the otherwise geographically keyed EAN coding system.
== History == Until January 1, 2007, all ISBNs were allocated as 9-digit numbers followed by a [[modular arithmetic|modulo]] 11 [[checksum]] character that was either a decimal digit or the letter X. A Bookland EAN was generated by concatenating the Bookland UCC 978, the 9 digits of the book's ISBN other than its checksum, and the EAN checksum digit.<ref>[https://www.isbn-information.com/the-13-digit-isbn.html Anatomy of a 13-digit ISBN]</ref><ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d5Z5I3gnFh0C&pg=PA265 |title=Elementary number theory with applications |author=Thomas Koshy}}</ref>
Since parts of the 10-character ISBN space are nearly full, all books published from 2007 on have been allocated a 13-digit [[ISBN]], which is identical to the Bookland EAN. Most of UCC 979 (formerly "Musicland") has now been assigned for the expansion of Bookland,<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KjveruEBBfoC&pg=PT41 |title=Book Marketing Demystified |author=Bruce Trelawny Batchelor}}</ref> and was first used by publishers in the French language, which can now use the additional prefix "979-10-" in addition to the nearly full "978-2-" prefix (onto which legacy 10-character ISBNs starting with "2-" have been remapped). Books numbered with prefixes other than 978 will not be mappable to 10-character ISBNs.
The GS1 is the global identification standards organization for retail. Every country has an assigned country code which precedes the company code. The "country codes" 978 and 979 are now officially registered for allocation by the [[International ISBN Agency]], which maintains the official international registry of ISBN numbers allocated to book publishers.
==Similar mappings==
* [[ISSN]]s (which identify [[periodical publication]]s) are mapped into the UCC 977.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jKcpAQAAIAAJ |title=International literary market place |year=1999}}</ref> * [[ISMN]]s (which identify [[sheet music]]) are mapped into the UCC 979. Since the leading "M" of a legacy 10-digit ISMN number (such as M-345-24680-5) is transcoded as 0, the EAN prefix 979-0 is wholly reserved for sheet music and has been dubbed the fictitious country "Musicland". Like ISBNs, ISMNs have been officially allocated using 13 digits since mid-2008.<ref>[http://ismn-international.org/download/GuidelinesGeneral.pdf Guidelines for the Implementation of 13-Digit ISMNs]</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080831082318/http://www.isbn.org/standards/home/isbn/transition.asp Are you ready for <nowiki>ISBN-13</nowiki>?] * [http://www.isbn-13.info Informational website which converts <nowiki>ISBN-10</nowiki> to <nowiki>ISBN-13</nowiki>] * [http://www.isbn-us.com US agency to obtain ISBN numbers] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070512012815/http://www.isbn-information.com/ean.html The EAN System]
[[Category:Book publishing]] [[Category:Fictional countries]] [[Category:International Standard Book Number]]
{{publish-stub}}

'''Bottled Ocean''' was an exhibition of work by New Zealand artists of Pacific Island descent that was shown at a number of metropolitan art galleries in New Zealand in 1994-1995. It featured the work artists who have become notable figures in New Zealand and internationally. ==Curatorial intent== Jim Vivieaere, a New Zealand artist of Rarotongan descent, was commissioned by touring exhibition company Exhibitour to curate an exhibition of contemporary Pacific Island artists. [[City Gallery Wellington]] was a partner in the exhibition.{{cite web|title=Bottled Ocean|url=http://citygallery.org.nz/exhibitions/bottled-ocean|website=City Gallery Wellington|accessdate=16 June 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Mahina-Tuai|first1=Kolokesa Uafa|title=Pacific arts in New Zealand - Visual art and literature'|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/44240/bottled-ocean-1994|website=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=16 June 2015|date=15 October 2014}} The exhibition was not a straightforward survey or 'celebration' of Pacific artists. Organising the exhibition turned Vivieaere into a spokesperson or authority on Pacific Island art, a position he was uneasy with.{{cite book|last1=Chiu|first1=Melissa|last2=Stevenson|first2=Karen|last3=Mason|first3=Ngahiraka|last4=Vercoe|first4=Caroline|title=Paradise now? : contemporary art from the Pacific|date=2004|publisher=David Bateman in association with Asia Society|location=Auckland|isbn=1869535847}}{{Rp|26}} He was concerned that the exhibition could lead to artists being pigeon-holed or 'ghettoised' or that stereotypes of the 'exotic' Pacific could be reinforced.{{Rp|26–27}} In one interview Vivieaere said that the ‘only reason we are here is that we are Polynesian – not on our merits but because we’re the "other"…. We don’t need Polynesian shows. I would like to see it as the last.’ ==Artists== Vivieaere selected a broad range of artists who worked in a variety of media and were at different stages of their careers. Most of them were born in New Zealand but had ties to [[Samoa]], [[Niue]], the [[Cook Islands]] and [[Tonga]].{{cite book|last1=Mallon|first1=Sean|last2=Pereira|first2=Pandora Fulimalo|title=Speaking in colour : conversations with artists of Pacific Island heritage|date=1997|publisher=Te Papa Press|location=Wellington|isbn=0909010447}}{{Rp|36}} Twenty-three artists formed the core exhibition: *[[Fatu Feu'u]] *William Furneaux *Patriq Futialo *Bruce George *[[Niki Hastings-McFall]] *[[Ioane Ioane]] *[[Lily Laita]] *Iosefa Leo *Simmie Nichols *Johnny Peninsula *Lyle Peninsula *Laugutu Poloai *[[John Pule]] *[[Ani O'Neill]] *Albert Refiti *Toegamau Tom Sefo *Greg Semu *Tania Short *[[Sopolemalama Filipe Tohi|Filipe Tohi]] *[[Michel Tuffery]] *Lape Fakalaga Tulisi *Veronica Vaevae *Loretta Young As the exhibition progressed other artists were added including Evotia Tamu, Sheyne Tuffery, Luana Asiata, Sasha Kronfeld, Glenda Vilisoni, Sale Jessop and the musical group Grace (made up of brothers Anthony, Jason and Paul Ioasa).{{cite web|title=Grace - profile|url=http://www.audioculture.co.nz/people/grace|website=AudioCulture|accessdate=16 June 2015}} ==Display== ''Bottled Ocean'' launched at City Gallery Wellington in 1994 and toured to [[Auckland Art Gallery]], Waikato Art Gallery (now [[Waikato Museum]]), the Manawatu Art Gallery (now [[Te Manawa]]) and the McDougall Art Annex (now [[Christchurch Art Gallery]]) throughout 1994 and 1995.{{Rp|33}} Vivieaere changed the display of the exhibition for each location. At City Gallery Wellington the works were displayed on a mirrored floor behind a perspex wall, mimicking museum cabinets or shop window displays. and creating a forced distance between the art and the viewer.{{Rp|136}} At the Auckland Art Gallery a mirrored floor was used and some of the works remained in their travelling crates or were partly unpacked. At the Robert McDougall Art Annex Michel Tuffery's sculpture ''Pisupo Lua Afe'', a life-size bull made out of flattened corned-beef cans, was positioned as if it was gazing at a wall of art works like a visitor.{{Rp|26}} ==Reception and influence== ''Bottled Ocean'' has been noted for being one of the first exhibitions to focus on contemporary Pacific artists and for its underlying concerns. The exhibition was discussed at length in the publication accompanying ''Paradise Now: Contemporary Art from the Pacific'', the first major exhibition of contemporary Pacific art to show in a United States museum. It is also discussed in the recent book ''Art in Oceania: A New History'':
''Bottled Ocean'' made the 'arrival' of contemporary Pacific art in the elite galleries of the New Zealand art world a problem to be reflected upon, rather than simply a triumph to celebrate. Having been invited to survey the work of Pacific migrants, Vivieaere turned the exhibition into something of an installation, a work of art in its own right, in which he used various exhibitionary devices to make the desire for 'cultural difference' and 'otherness', which had become broadly topical in the artworld, the implicit subject of the exhibition.{{cite book|last1=Brunt|first1=Peter|last2=Nicholas|first2=Thomas|title=Art in Oceania : a new history|date=2013|publisher=Thames and Hudson|location=London|isbn=0500239010}}{{Rp|432}}
Reviewing the exhibition for ''Art AsiaPacific'' Wendy Vaigro wrote
As the ostensible organising principle of ''Bottled Ocean'', 'Pacific Islandness' is utilised as a term that references, ironically, attempts to homogenise Polynesian artists working in New Zealand. ... In challenging the closure of aesthetic and political categories and conventional curatorial practices, Jim Vivieaere creates ''Bottled Ocean'' as a meta-exhibition. The result is a subtle and thoughtful show that eludes ideological control and authoritative discourse at every turn.{{cite journal|last1=Vaigro|first1=Wendy|title=''Bottled Ocean": Shape Shifting|journal=Art AsiaPacific|date=1995|volume=2|issue=4|pages=44–45}}
In a review for ''Art New Zealand'', [[Nicholas Thomas]] investigated Vivieaere's reference to a 'modern tribal art market' in the brochure accompanying the exhibition.{{cite journal|last1=Thomas|first1=Nicholas|title=Pacific Dualities: Bottled Ocean in Wellington and Auckland|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Autumn 1995|issue=74|pages=46–50}} He observed that 'the work in ''Bottled Ocean'' is produced for and around a market - not just an art market, but a contemporary global cultural market, a multicultural theatre in which identities, signatures, nationalities and lifestyles are affirmed, celebrated, changed and consumed.'.{{Rp|46}} He continued:
The mainstream audience may be primarily interested in the tropical colourfulness of the work, in the apparent conformity of its spirituality with New Age environmentalism, in its exoticism. Artists appear to have responded to this interest by making exoticism visually explicit through the use of readily recognizable Polynesian motifs. ... The distinctive accomplishment of ''Bottled Ocean'' lies in its direct but subtle challenge to this consumerist interest interest in Pacific art and culture.{{Rp|47–48}}
==Further information== *[http://www.the-tls.co.uk/tls/public/article1243191.ece Review of ''Art in Oceania: A New History''] discussing ''Bottled Ocean'' in the ''Times Literary Supplement'' (2013) *[http://artasiapacific.com/News/JimVivieaere19472011 Obituary of Jim Vivieaere], ''Art AsiaPacific'' (2011) == References== {{Reflist|2}} [[Category:Indigenous art]] [[Category:1994 in New Zealand]] [[Category:Art exhibitions]] [[Category:Art exhibitions in New Zealand]]

Replacing Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Socialist_Republic_of_Serbia.svg with [[File:Coat_of_arms_of_Serbia_(1947–2004).svg]] (by [[commons:User:CommonsDelinker|CommonsDelinker]] because: [[:c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: added usage dates.).
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2011}} {{refimprove|date=February 2008}} {{Infobox coat of arms |name = Coat of arms of Kosovo |image = Coat of arms of Kosovo.svg |image_width = 250 |middle = |middle_width = |middle_caption = |lesser = |lesser_alt = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |armiger = [[Kosovo|Republic of Kosovo]] |year_adopted = {{start date and age|2008|02|17|df=yes}} |crest = |torse = |shield = Azure, a map of Kosovo Or beneath six mullets embowed argent, all within a bordure Or. |supporters = |compartment = |motto = |orders = |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''[[coat of arms]] of the [[Kosovo|Republic of Kosovo]]{{ref label|status|a|}}''' was introduced following the [[2008 Kosovo declaration of independence|unilateral declaration of independence]] from [[Serbia]], issued by [[Kosovo]]'s parliament in the country's capital on February 17, 2008. It shows six white stars in an arc above a solid golden shape of Kosovo as seen on a standard projection map, placed on a rounded triangular shield with a blue field and a golden border.[http://www.kosovapress.com/ks/index.php?cid=2,2,38793 Kosovo's emblem which is expected to be adopted today in the parliament]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Kosovapress'', Pristina, February 17, 2008. Its central figures, the stars and the shape, are also the content of the new blue [[flag of Kosovo]], already adopted at the same time. ==Symbols used during United Nations administration== The United Nations Mission in Kosovo (UNMIK) issued two regulations relating to the use of symbols: *UNMIK regulation UNMIK/REG/2000/30[http://www.unmikonline.org/regulations/2000/reg30-00.htm Regulations – 2000] (May 20, 2000) "ON STAMPS AND HEADINGS OF OFFICIAL DOCUMENTS OF COURTS, PROSECUTORS’ OFFICES AND PENAL ESTABLISHMENTS" states that the seals and letter heads of courts and penal establishments should contain "The emblem of the United Nations with “UNMIK” added to the top of the emblem" and the word "“Kosovo” in Albanian, Serbian and English" *ADMINISTRATIVE DIRECTION NO. 2003/15http://www.unmikonline.org/regulations/admdirect/2003/ade2003_15.pdfhttp://www.unmikonline.org/regulations/admdirect/2003/ADE2003_15_AnnexI.pdf(July 2, 2003) "IMPLEMENTING UNMIK REGULATION NO. 2001/9 ON A CONSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK FOR PROVISIONAL SELF-GOVERNMENT IN KOSOVO" Establishes an "approved logo" for the Provisional Institutions of Self Government. File:Unmik logo.JPG|Logo of the [[United Nations Mission in Kosovo]] File:Coat of arms of the PISG of Kosovo.svg|The Approved Logo of the [[Provisional Institutions of Self-Government]] (2003-2008) == Historical emblems == File:Coa Serbia Country History (Fojnica Armorial) (14th century).svg|14th-century coat of arms, [[Fojnica Armorial]] (between 1675-1688) File:Coat of arms of Kingdom of Serbia (1718–39).svg|coat of arms of [[Kingdom of Serbia (1718-39)]] File:Nemanjić dynasty Stemmatographia.jpg|[[Serbian Empire]], [[Hristofor Žefarović]]'s ''Stemmatographia'' (1741) File:Грб Србије (Из Стематографије).jpg|Serbian coat of arms, ''Stemmatographia'' (1741) File:Praviteljstvujušči sovjet serbski.JPG|Government seal
([[First Serbian Uprising]], 1805–1813) File:Grb 1ustanak.JPG|[[Karađorđe]]'s seal
(1804–1813) File:Coat of Arms of the Principality of Serbia.png|[[Principality of Serbia]]
(1835–1882) File:Royal Coat of arms of Serbia (1882–1918).svg|[[Kingdom of Serbia]] (1882–1918) File:Coat of arms of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia.svg|[[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] (1918–1944) File:Coat of arms of Nedics Serbia.svg|[[Government of National Salvation]] (1941-1944) File:Coat of arms of Serbia (1947–2004).svg|[[Socialist Republic of Serbia]] (1947–1990) and [[Republic of Serbia (1992–2006)|Republic of Serbia]] (1990–2004) File:Coat of arms of Albania (1992-1998).svg|[[Republic of Kosova]] (1992–1999) File:Coat of arms of Serbia and Montenegro.svg|Coat of arms of the [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] (1992-2003) and the [[State Union of Serbia and Montenegro]] (2003–2006) File:Royal Coat of arms of Serbia (1882–1918).svg|[[Serbia|Republic of Serbia]] (2006–2010) File:Coat of arms of Serbia.svg|[[Serbia|Republic of Serbia]] (2010–present) == See also == {{portal|Kosovo|Serbia}} {{commonscat|Coats of arms of Kosovo}} *[[Flag of Kosovo]] *[[Coat of arms of Serbia]] ==Notes== *a.  {{note|status}}{{Kosovo-note}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Kosovo topics|state=collapsed}} {{Coats of arms of Europe}} {{Serbia topics}} [[Category:National coats of arms|Kosovo]] [[Category:National symbols of Kosovo]] [[Category:Coats of arms with stars|Kosovo]] [[Category:Coats of arms with maps|Kosovo]] [[Category:Serbian coats of arms|Kosovo]]
